channel.title: Artificial Trees to soak up CO2
channel.description:
Watched this on a program.. these trees are pretty cool and they reckon a fully grown one will soak up 75 car's worth of CO2 A DAY! And they can be planted anywhere in the world and they think if they plant 60 million of these it will get rid of the worlds pollution altogether. All these trees need is a water supply Source: http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/8223528.stm
Engineers say a forest of 100,000 "artificial trees" could be deployed within 10 to 20 years to help soak up the world's carbon emissions. The trees are among three geo-engineering ideas highlighted as practical in a new report. The authors from the Institution of Mechanical Engineers say that without geo-engineering it will be impossible to avoid dangerous climate change. The report includes a 100-year roadmap to "decarbonise" the global economy. No silver bullet Launching the report, lead author Dr Tim Fox said geo-engineering should not be viewed as a "silver bullet" that could combat climate change in isolation. He told BBC News it should be used in conjunction with efforts to reduce carbon emissions and to adapt to the effects of climate change. Many climate scientists calculate that the world has only a few decades to reduce emissions before there is so much carbon dioxide in the atmosphere that a dangerous rise in global temperature is inevitable. FROM THE TODAY PROGRAMME More from Today programme The authors of this report say that geo-engineering of the type they propose should be used on a short-term basis to buy the world time, but in the long term it is vital to reduce emissions. They define two types of geo-engineering. Nem Vaughan of University of East Anglia said: "The first category attempts to cool the planet by reflecting some of the sunlight away. The problem with this is that it just masks the problem." "The other type of geo-engineering is to remove carbon dioxide from the atmosphere and store it." Hundreds of options The team studied hundreds of different options but have put forward just three as being practical and feasible using current technology. A key factor in choosing the three was that they should be low-carbon technologies rather than adding to the problem. Dr Fox told BBC News: "Artificial trees are already at the prototype stage and are very advanced in their design in terms of their automation and in the components that would be used. "They could, within a relatively short duration, be moved forward into mass production and deployment." The trees would work on the principle of capturing carbon dioxide from the air through a filter. The CO2 would then be removed from the filter and stored. The report calls for the technology to be developed in conjunction with carbon storage infrastructure. artificial trees The captured carbon dioxide could be stored in empty north sea oil wells Dr Fox said the prototype artificial tree was about the same size as a shipping container and could remove thousands of times more carbon dioxide from the atmosphere than an equivalent sized real tree. Another of the team's preferred methods of capturing carbon is to install what they term "algae based photobioreactors" on buildings. These would be transparent containers containing algae which would remove carbon dioxide from the air during photosynthesis. buildings with algae units Algae units could be designed into new buildings or retrofitted to old ones The third option focuses on the reduction of incoming solar radiation by reflecting sunlight back into space. The report says the simplest way of doing this is for buildings to have reflective roofs. The authors stress that all of these options will require more research and have called for the UK government to invest 10 million pounds in analysis of the effectiveness, risks and costs of geo-engineering. Dr Fox said: "We very much believe that the practical geo-engineering that we are proposing should be implemented and could be very much part of our landscape within the next 10 to 20 years."

item.title: Artificial Trees to soak up CO2
item.dc:creator: @Rawrmoan Rawrmoan
item.description:
@Rawrmoan wrote:

[quote=“inertia, post:50, topic:318787”][quote author=Rawrmoan link=topic=415249.msg3060571#msg3060571 date=1260827224]

[quote author=inertia link=topic=415249.msg3060561#msg3060561 date=1260826878]@Rawrmoan: dioxygen is just oxygen - O2, not O. You don’t just get free radicals floating around you know :rolleyes:. Actually a lot of your post sounded like you made it up on the spot with a bit of GCSE chemistry/physics thrown in for good measure.
[/quote]No where did I say dioxygen was just O? I said O was a diatomic oxygen atom. Actually though chlorine is heavier than oxygen and nitrogen which make up our atmosphere constant changing in wind pressure can cause it to rise in the atmosphere faster than it can fall, when this chlorine is hit by ultraviolet waves, you get a free radical correct?
[/quote]

Yes, you get a chlorine free radical which attacks an ozone molecule to produce a ClO free radical and oxygen (or dioxygen as you like to call it). Then the ClO free radical can be considered to attack a single oxygen atom to produce another oxygen molecule (O2) and another chlorine free radical which continues the chain reaction.[/quote]It was a typo, I know di refers to two in dioxygen (O2).

Read full topic
item.source: Artificial Trees to soak up CO2

item.title: Artificial Trees to soak up CO2
item.dc:creator: @inertia inertia
item.description:
@inertia wrote:

[quote=“Rawrmoan, post:47, topic:318787”][quote author=inertia link=topic=415249.msg3060561#msg3060561 date=1260826878]@Rawrmoan: dioxygen is just oxygen - O2, not O. You don’t just get free radicals floating around you know :rolleyes:. Actually a lot of your post sounded like you made it up on the spot with a bit of GCSE chemistry/physics thrown in for good measure.
[/quote]No where did I say dioxygen was just O? I said O was a diatomic oxygen atom. Actually though chlorine is heavier than oxygen and nitrogen which make up our atmosphere constant changing in wind pressure can cause it to rise in the atmosphere faster than it can fall, when this chlorine is hit by ultraviolet waves, you get a free radical correct?[/quote]

Yes, you get a chlorine free radical which attacks an ozone molecule to produce a ClO free radical and oxygen (or dioxygen as you like to call it). Then the ClO free radical can be considered to attack a single oxygen atom to produce another oxygen molecule (O2) and another chlorine free radical which continues the chain reaction.

Read full topic

@Rawrmoan wrote:

R3volution`:

[quote]to produce dioxygen (O)

[quote]which react with more dioxygen to produce ozone. O2 + O = 03.
[/quote]

Nice.[/quote]That was a typo meant to be dioxygen (O2). When it says reacts with more dioxygen it’s referring to the atomic atom (O) reacting with dioxygen (O2) to make ozone (O3).

item.title: Artificial Trees to soak up CO2
item.dc:creator: @inertia inertia
item.description:
@inertia wrote:

Supermarkets just need to be forced to not do business with suppliers which use too much packaging. Then the suppliers will soon learn that the entire market is in the same situation as them and all they need to do is reduce the packaging they put on their products to start selling to supermarkets again.

As for growing the goods locally instead of importing them - this will most definitely not cause an economic depression. Big companies are gaining significant profits by mass executing this process, but to the average consumer the price increase shouldn’t even be noticeable. I know some things have to be imported, like bananas, pineapples, Spanish ham etc, but other stuff that can be sourced locally should be.

@Rawrmoan: dioxygen is just oxygen - O2, not O. You don’t just get free radicals floating around you know :rolleyes:. Actually a lot of your post sounded like you made it up on the spot with a bit of GCSE chemistry/physics thrown in for good measure.

Read full topic
item.source: Artificial Trees to soak up CO2

item.title: Artificial Trees to soak up CO2
item.dc:creator: @Rawrmoan Rawrmoan
item.description:
@Rawrmoan wrote:

Hmm I don’t think CO2 emissions are what is causing the climatic shift in temperature. Chlorofluorocarbons are used in various aerosols and have found their way through air currents to the ice poles of the Earth, where they react with ozone (O3) to produce dioxygen (O2). During the winter periods when each pole is receiving such less ultraviolet light because the Earth is spherical and when the light hits the poles of the Earth it is distributed more evenly, the dioxygen is not being converted back to ozone (which evidently blocks ultraviolet frequencies). So the poles are heating and melting. Dioxygen is converted back to ozone by ultraviolet electromagnetic waves splitting them into diatomic oxygen atoms, which react with more dioxygen to produce ozone. O2 + O = 03.

Read full topic
item.source: Artificial Trees to soak up CO2

item.title: Artificial Trees to soak up CO2
item.dc:creator: @R3volution1 R3volution`
item.description:
@R3volution1 wrote:

[quote=“eczema3, post:43, topic:318787”][quote author=inertia link=topic=415249.msg3060506#msg3060506 date=1260825080]
Like cleaning out our jam pots so they can be ‘recycled’? Let’s not forget about the massive supermarket chains who continue to sell products with far too much packaging, and fly in standard fruit & veg just because the labour costs work out a bit cheaper. And the mass production factories in China polluting like there’s no tomorrow. Setting stricter laws around this sort of stuff would be a much better idea than wasting time telling people to not leave their tv’s on standby and to turn the tap off between brushing your teeth.
[/quote]

But stricter laws would send the world into economic depression, shops would put prices up because the cost of growing/creating/importing the products that the laws have been set on will be higher.[/quote]

What about if they crackdown on packaging? Many companies put way too much packaging on their own products to include things which makes their content stand out. It will save money.

Read full topic

inertia:

Like cleaning out our jam pots so they can be ‘recycled’? Let’s not forget about the massive supermarket chains who continue to sell products with far too much packaging, and fly in standard fruit & veg just because the labour costs work out a bit cheaper. And the mass production factories in China polluting like there’s no tomorrow. Setting stricter laws around this sort of stuff would be a much better idea than wasting time telling people to not leave their tv’s on standby and to turn the tap off between brushing your teeth.

But stricter laws would send the world into economic depression, shops would put prices up because the cost of growing/creating/importing the products that the laws have been set on will be higher.

item.title: Artificial Trees to soak up CO2
item.dc:creator: @inertia inertia
item.description:
@inertia wrote:

[quote=“R3volution`, post:40, topic:318787”][quote author=inertia link=topic=415249.msg3060173#msg3060173 date=1260803528]

Back then glacial activity like this triggered massive rises in the oceans levels. Its going to gradually get warmer since glaciers deflect approximately 80% sunlight, and 20% isnt. And of course, when theres less of thse glaciers, theres a reverse in that sequence.

Its a periodic occurence in the Earths history, so we shouldnt all go crazy over this.

Who cares if it’s a periodic occurrence? If the climate is going to change and kill us all then we need to do something about it, not sit here saying “oh it’s just a natural event so we’re okay”. Not that I fully agree with any of the theories proposed for the cause of global warming (or the lack of) because I don’t have any of my own research and there are so many conflicting factors in a situation like this.
[/quote]

When did I say it was okay? I never said it was okay, moreover we shouldnt be rampaging about this since our governments have the power to actually do something. They just arent doing good enough. And its not just them that needs to do something about it, we do as well.[/quote]

Like cleaning out our jam pots so they can be ‘recycled’? Let’s not forget about the massive supermarket chains who continue to sell products with far too much packaging, and fly in standard fruit & veg just because the labour costs work out a bit cheaper. And the mass production factories in China polluting like there’s no tomorrow. Setting stricter laws around this sort of stuff would be a much better idea than wasting time telling people to not leave their tv’s on standby and to turn the tap off between brushing your teeth.

Read full topic

@R3volution1 wrote:

[quote=“inertia, post:39, topic:318787”][quote author=R3volution` link=topic=415249.msg3058950#msg3058950 date=1260719973]
Back then glacial activity like this triggered massive rises in the oceans levels. Its going to gradually get warmer since glaciers deflect approximately 80% sunlight, and 20% isnt. And of course, when theres less of thse glaciers, theres a reverse in that sequence.

Its a periodic occurence in the Earths history, so we shouldnt all go crazy over this.
[/quote]

Who cares if it’s a periodic occurrence? If the climate is going to change and kill us all then we need to do something about it, not sit here saying “oh it’s just a natural event so we’re okay”. Not that I fully agree with any of the theories proposed for the cause of global warming (or the lack of) because I don’t have any of my own research and there are so many conflicting factors in a situation like this.[/quote]

When did I say it was okay? I never said it was okay, moreover we shouldnt be rampaging about this since our governments have the power to actually do something. They just arent doing good enough. And its not just them that needs to do something about it, we do as well.

Read full topic
